review_title: Great job long term, just gotta make it past two years
job_title: Assembly Line Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: This is a great job in the long run. After 4 years you will be making around $30/hr. The benefits are good, especially if you have a whole family, adding people onto the insurance is free, no extra cost. You get the A plan for buying Ford vehicles on day 1. Work can fly by if you are able to mindlessly work and drown everything out. And the work isn’t as hard as everybody says it is… kinda. There are A LOT of different jobs, so I can’t speak on all of them. Weekly pay. Different shifts (after the 2 year mark) that can cater to anybodys lifestyle.
cons:
As of 5-28-2022, (different contracts may change this) and regarding only the Chicago Assembly Plant, When starting work, you are considered a TFT (Temporary Full Time). This means you have no leniency until you pass the 2 year max mark of being a TFT and are automatically converted to Full Time, or if a new contract is set in place and you are automatically turned over. This also means you are treated like garbage by anybody who has been converted to full time, or who doesn’t work for the UAW Union and works directly for Ford. You can’t ever be late, or you’ll be fired. You can’t take any off time in these 2 years unless you have a bulletproof excuse with all of your bases covered. You cannot get a raise while being a TFT. You don’t get insurance or any benefits besides the A plan until the 90th day worked. Not “90 days after hire” but actually 90th day worked, which comes out to be around your 6th month of working. You don’t get holiday pay until you pass the 90th working day.

There seems to be many layoffs right now, which can be a pro or a con depending on how you look at it, because of the constant parts shortages that have to plagued the world since 2020. You also can’t file for unemployment while being under your 90th working day.

Managers don’t seem to know any questions you ask them, since you work for Fords Union, and they work for Ford directly. So information on any topic you need to know about is incredibly hard to get, and could take weeks or months to find simple things out. Even the people who work for the Union who should know this information most of the time don’t, because when they got hired in, TFTs were not a thing, therefore they mostly know nothing about what a TFT can and can’t do.

Orientation is mostly all bs. There may have been only 1 or 2 correct things learned in orientation, but other than that, it’s almost all just copy and paste phrases they legally need to tell you. Once you get on the floor, pretty much everything they told you about goes out the window. (Besides *some* of the safety tips they told you.)

Work life balance is pretty awful. Especially as a TFT. Once you turn full time you will work about 4 days a week which is nice, but as a TFT you work 5-6 days a week. Great pay, terrible work/life balance though. 

They will ask you if you want to work on your off day or not, but if too many people decline the offer, they force everyone to work anyway.

At the Chicago Assembly plant specifically, when starting, you will be sent the the “Sho Center” which isn’t the Chicago Assembly Plant. It’s a different building. It’s only A shift, and there is no pay differential.
